  38. This scale was purchased to replace one that read 6 lbs too heavy, along with other failing functions on it ie bodyfat test, etc. I like the aesthetic appearance, the blue led light is bright enough to read even in the dark. The most important thing for me was its accurate and looks good! No bodyfat tester on this model, which is fine. The digital read out is sharp and the scale does all the work. Pop in the included batteries and make sure the scale reads 0.0 before stepping on,simple. The batteries are rated to last a year, if you weigh yourself less than 3 times a day. Check it out!
  39. Love the lighted dial. Nice, big numbers too. Slim, easy to use. It is easy to calibrate if moved. You just tap it, the light goes on, then goes off in 10 seconds. Done.   44. I needed a good, accurate bathroom scale so I headed to Amazon like usual. Once I started reading the reviews, I was amazed at the fierce competition in the bathroom scale world...and unfortunately all the fake reviews and bribed reviews made it near impossible to figure out what to buy.<br /><br />I eliminated the brand with the gazillion reviews on all their scales after reading that their reviewers were promised free goods among other things if they left a good review. I had a tough time figuring out if the haters on the other ones were real and those scales were garbage, or if they were also paid off (someone mentioned that reviewers get paid on elance - for good and bad reviews).<br /><br />So here I was, wanting to eat cookies but not knowing if I'd gain 20 pounds from said cookies. Do I eat 2, 4 or 10? What would the weighty damage be? I was in a real pickle without a scale!<br /><br />I checked out the Omega brand and overall they seemed the least controversial (and Amazon is awesome about returns) so I took a chance on this one. I'm glad I did. It works. It's accurate (yes lady that asks everyone if they put weights on it to test it...I actually did that). It has big numbers I can read easily so that I know to either stop eating cookies or go ahead and have another. Best of all, it's simple. I need simple, life is complicated enough I don't want to have to get a master's degree to figure out how to operate my bathroom scale.<br /><br />I use it every day and it has performed perfectly every single day. When it comes to weighing myself, that part of my life is simple and dependable thanks to this scale. I highly recommend it.<br /><br />UPDATED AUGUST 2014 - this is still working fantastically. It agrees with the scales at my doctors offices so I'm happy. Three years with this scale and no signs of it quitting anytime soon.

  51. My original review is below. All that was true until recently. I had the scale for about 6 weeks then suddenly and for no apparent reason it will no longer lock onto a weight. The display just keeps fluctuating no matter how long I wait until it times out and goes dark. If I step off the scale before that, the weight decreases as I'm getting off until it shows 00, instead of showing my weight for about 20 seconds as it used to.<br /><br />I never abused it in any way. It wasn't even in a damp bathroom. I kept it in the bedroom on a hardwood floor. Just one day it worked great and the next time I used it a few days later, I couldn't get a reading. It lasted just long enough to prevent me from getting a refund.<br /><br />-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------<br /><br />Once you've gotten past the confusing set up instructions this is a very nice scale. A label on it tells you to \\"auto-calibrate\\" and says, \\"Place scale on floor and allow to turn off without stepping on the scale\\". Huh? It doesn't even go on w/o stepping on it, so how can you \\"allow it to turn off\\"? The separate instructions inside the box say that each time you move it you should turn it on by stepping on it, then letting it turn off after \\"or the scale will add its own weight\\" to the number displayed. (And give the person getting weighed a panic attack.) Turns out, what these two things mean is that after the first time you put it down for use, and every time you lift it to clean or to move it somewhere else, you have to step on briefly, just long enough for the display to read \\"00\\" & not long enough to show a weight, and get right off, leaving it alone until the display goes dark. From then on until you pick it up again it will stay correctly calibrated.<br /><br />Nice things about it: it comes w/ its own batteries; it's fashionably thin; it's large enough for the display to be visible even if you've got a bit of a belly; the display is well-lit and large; the display stays on for about 20 seconds after you get off so if you are too big to see it when you're on the scale, you can still see what you weigh; it doesn't wobble even if the floor is not absolutely flat; it doesn't have a bunch of excess functions most of us don't want b/c if we're obsessive enough to be weighing ourselves at home we don't need a scale to track our weight (do you really want to have to tell it each time that it's you & not your SO being weighed b/c it's tracking 2 people's weights?).<br /><br />While I can't swear it's accurate, the weights I've been getting seem to make sense. Can't think of any negatives, but I don't yet know about its durability.

  62. I have a beaten-up, Taylor scale, that's about ten, plus, years old. I resisted getting rid of it, because it's the most accurate scale I've ever owned. It's spot-on with my Dr's very expensive scale and the scale at my workplace. But, in the last few months, it has gotten quirky. It remains accurate, but I have to jump around on it like a trampoline, to make it come on. It was time to say goodbye to my old faithful friend. It's so sad; we've shared so many diets together; so many successes and failures. Sigh!<br /><br />I'm not sure why I settled on the Omega, with SO many choices, but I'm glad that I did. The scale is very thin and modern in appearance. It would be attractive in any setting and, it functions exactly as advertised.<br /><br />I love the features including: auto on, the extra large LCD display, the weight units in kg, or lbs, the 0.2 lb graduation and the fact that it does come with batteries to get you started. I'm also glad there is a \\"lo\\" battery indicator.<br /><br />Your weight is locked in, for approximately 10 seconds, after weighing. How cool is that! This affords an extra 10 seconds to berate yourself for failure, or maybe to bask in the victory of dropping a couple of pounds. More seriously, it would also be great for someone having trouble seeing around their expansive tummy---or perhaps to weigh yourself and then yourself with an object you would like to weigh---like your toddler, or the dog.<br /><br />Popping in the batteries and, weighing in for the first time, only took a couple of minutes. And, I'm ecstatic, because I obtained the same weight as my old Taylor scale.<br /><br />Because of the clean lines of the scale, it appears it will be very easy to keep clean, which is a bonus, too. I'm wondering about battery life, because this thing lights up like a landing strip, but it sure does make it easy to see, particularly if stumbling into the bathroom first thing in the morning, sans glasses or contacts.<br /><br />I think this would be a great scale for seniors, or anyone with balance issues. The platform is large enough to accommodate almost everyone, unless you're Charles Barkley, but it's so low to the ground, that it might prevent stumbling.<br /><br />Yes, I'm tickled pink! Of course durability will remain to be seen, since it has only just arrived. But in spite of being so thin, it appears sturdy and well made. We'll see, but right now, I'm happy, happy.<br /><br />ONE YEAR anniversary (May 2011) UPDATE: My Omega is still going strong, on the same batteries that came with it, one year ago. It has been used two, to three times daily, for the last year. Accuracy remains dependable, and, it shows no wear. A little wipe-down, and it looks exactly like it did right out of the box. So, in conclusion, I'm still happy, happy!<br /><br />Update 06/24/13: Still functioning well, looks like new, AND, still with the same battery.s would be a great scale for seniors, or anyone with balance issues. The platform is large enough to accommodate almost everyone, unless you're Charles Barkley, but it's so low to the ground, that it might prevent stumbling.<br /><br />Yes, I'm tickled pink!   145. I have stepped on many different scales but find this one the best of all bathroom scales I have been on, either at others houses or my own.<br /><br />This one is small enough to be put out of the way easy, is extremely consistent, never varying a single ounce.<br /><br />They are self calibrating, to calibrate one only needs to tap on the scale, wait for about 6 seconds for it to set itself to zero.<br /><br />If you are oversize and cannot see the weight, like I am, no problem, the weight light stays on for about 5 seconds after stepping off of them. Very well lit, easy to read.<br /><br />And for the ladies, very attractive scales. For the men, myself being one, they are very sturdy made, which I like a lot. The platform is of thick clear glass over the scales weight mechanisms, all covered attractively with a neutral tone color band about two inches wide.<br /><br />I am very glad to have selected this set and highly recommend them to all.<br /><br />J W
  146. This scale replaced an older dial model that had about a five pound swing, depending on how my feet were positioned and weight was shifted. And while this scale does have a memory - in that it will repeat exactly the same weight if I step on it twice in a row - that measure can be defeated when I pick up a bath towel to add 3/4 of a pound, then weigh again without it. My husband weighs about 225 and I'm at about 135; both of us get consistent and seemingly accurate readings. Scales are supposed to give accurate weights. I don't need a BMI measurement or other bells and whistles. This scale does what it's supposed to do, and at a very reasonable price. It arrived in perfect condition, was well packaged and came quickly. Set-up took about two minutes.

  149. This is a fancy and expensive looking scale...well, to me anyways. It's easy to set up. All you need to do is put in the batteries (that come with it) and set it down on a flat surface then you're ready to go.<br /><br />***Edit: 8/31/2013***<br /><br />If you step on it just right you'll tip it over to the side. Sometimes the weight is off so I would have to take out the batteries and put them back in to get my \\"real\\" weight. Overall, pretty decent scale.
  150. After using this Omega digital scale for two months, I can't really find anything to complain about for a scale in the twenty five dollar price range. What I need from a scale is the numbers to go up when gaining weight, go down when losing weight and stay the same when no changes. And this is what I got from this one. I measured multiple times before and after meals, with and without a coat, before and after an output operation, and the numbers were consistently higher when you expected them to be higher, and lower when you expected them to be lower. It also correlated with other factors (how belts and pants feel when gaining/losing weight, etc).<br /><br />One point to note, I did not compare its measurements with professional gym and medical scales, so I can't tell you how it performs in that fashion.<br /><br />The scale takes four AAA batteries, inserted in pairs of two on the bottom side of the device (upper left and upper right corners). Four Industrial brand single use AAA batteries were included in the box. The blue backlight is a nice touch and very easy to read. The scale shows weight in 0.2 lb increments. You can switch from Kilos to Pounds and vice versa by pressing the button located on the bottom side of the device (upper area, in the middle of the top row).<br /><br />To weigh yourself, simply step on it, and it will turn on and start measuring. No need to tap the corner like my previous scale, which I found rather annoying.<br /><br />It needs to be placed on a flat surface, and if you move it, you have to recalibrate it, which, based on reading the tea leaves in the four page user manual, means to tap on the main surface briefly to turn on, not step on it, let it measure 0, then let it turn off on its own, and then measure yourself as usual. Or you can remove and reinsert the batteries.<br /><br />Speaking of the four page user manual, it looks like it was written with computer translation or using a dictionary. Tortured sentences and typos it has,but it manages to communicate what needs to be communicate. Of the four pages, two of them are the meat, the other two pages are the front cover and back cover :)

  214. This scale is basically a rebadged Escali US180B Ultra Slim Bathroom Scale. Although I have the Escali scale, the review should apply equally to this scale.<br /><br />Pros:<br />- Very slim, compact, and storable<br />- Large LCD readout<br />- Attractive design<br /><br />Cons:<br />- Very inconsistent weights<br /><br />I bought this scale because Consumer Reports had highly recommended several Escali scales (though they didn't review this one). I love that it is compact and attractive. The problem is that it just doesn't work for someone who is trying to track your weight because it is so inconsistent.<br /><br />Example:<br />One day, I weighed myself ten times within 20mins. These are the weights that came out.<br />1: 148.2<br />2: 148.2<br />3: 147.8<br />4: 147.8<br />5: 147.8<br />6: 147.8<br />7: 147.8<br />8: 148.4<br />9: 148.4<br />10: 148.2<br /><br />With in twenty minutes there was more than half a pound of variation in my measured weight! Sometimes it it is worse. Last week, there was a two pound difference when I weighed myself in succession. This destroys any confidence I have in this scale for tracking my weight.<br /><br />I thought the error in this scale would be relative to my true weight, but there the error seems to be redrawn each time you step on the scale. I don't need to know whether I weigh exactly 148.2, but I do need a scale which will accurately capture my weight changes. This scale doesn't cut it.<br /><br />I am going to be purchasing an analog scale as it seems that many digital scale suffer from this problem. Even Consumer Reports admitted that the analog scales they reviewed were much more consistent than the best digital scales. Even though the analog scales may not get your true weight exactly right, they will deliver exactly the same reading every time if you weight doesn't change. If you want to track your weight changes and care about a 0.5lbs like I do, then get a good analog scale.<br /><br />If you found this review helpful let me know with your vote. :)

Close monitoring of my weight is important to me while I have been on a weight loss program and while adjusting my eating and activity to maintain that loss. So I was happy that it could weigh within a 2/10s of a pound. I hadn't found any scale to do better except for my WII which weighed within 1/10th of a pound. So I was very disappointed when the scale started being very erratic and varying by about 7 pounds during a weighing before settling on a weight that I know is way off. Then if I weigh immediately again it will behave similarly and come up with a completely different weight. When it started doing this I replaced all four batteries with new good quality batteries and it did not improve at all. I can not tell how to contact the company directly about the problem and being out of the country it is inconvenient to just order another one from Amazon. A mechanical scale will probably work for decades but an electronic scale can have problems. I knew this but hoped that this electronic scale would work for years.<br /><br />Update. Don't give up too soon if your scale seems off. Somehow mine started functioning perfectly well again. Maybe it was a battery issue .

Until now, I have been relying on the balance type scales at the gym with varying degrees of accuracy with wide variations on different days. I sometimes would gain as much as 5 pounds in one day! I finally decided to get a digital scale for my home, and I picked this one based on the price and the overall positive reviews. Setup was very easy. Once you install the batteries, you place it on the floor where it will reside and lightly step on it to turn it on until it reads zero to calibrate the scale. Then it is ready to use. Once you step on it, the weight will be determined, then flashes once the reading has stabilized. The readings are very consistent as well.

  294. O.K., it's just a Digital Scale for home usage right... My mission was to give my wife a Digital Scale as a nice surprise gift. Well after looking & reviewing the dozens of makes, models, reviews, pricing, perceived quality of manufacture, etc. in Amazon... I simply chose this model. I have an Electronics Engineering background, and believe they are all made in China (big surprise, right), and they probably all have the same -or nearly the same- \\"Strain/Weight Pressure Sensor Piezoelectric Crystals\\" (that's the actual \\"techno\\" for how most all these type scales work) which converts Mechanical Forces (weight) into an Electrical force (voltage & current), that feeds the Electronic Measuring Circuitry. The batteries (2 AAA type) are primarily used for the Digital LED numerical display. So O.K., now that you have, but did not ask for, or need to know \\"how they work\\"... Bottom line, hey this Scale works, reads very accurate, nice Blue Numbers, is aesthetically nice looking, and the wife is happy! Hence a winner.
  295. This is a very nice and simple piece of equipment. When we got it, all we had to do was put the batteries in and set it on the ground and it was ready to use. Especially if you are not looking for one that is supposed to read your percent body fat. I definitely recommend this scale to anyone looking for a good functional and professional looking scale.

  326. After reading a million reviews on scales with many people complaining of accuracy I finally decided on this one. It comes with a removable sticker that instructs you to re-calibrate it when moved.<br />I was skeptical about the accuracy, so I did the standard dumbell test with 2x20lb, 2x10lb and 2x8lb weights. Well, it's definitely accurate. And my 10lb weights are not actually 10lbs each...<br />It's a no-tap, just step-on scale which is nice. You step on, it continuously reads the weight until the weight is not changing, flashes the weight on the screen a few times and stays on for a few seconds once you've gotten off. Simple, effective.   335. My wife and I weren't looking for a health-club-quality scale. We wanted something that could be seen reasonably well in different lighting conditions and didn't take up too much space. The best part about the scale is you just \\"step on.\\" No extra \\"press to turn on,\\" then step on. You may not think that extra step matters, but think about what you could do with an extra 2 or 3 seconds each day, plus the joy of not having to remember a two-sequence behavior chain in the morning behavior you've had your coffee. If multiple people are using the scale, the time-saving quality is, of course, multiplied.<br /><br />In short, this is a great, slim, no nonsense scale that is very easy to use. Not for those who want to calculate body fat %, a WiFi connection, or an mp3 player.
  336. After using an analog scale for so long (that always had to be calibrated), I finally broke down and ordered a digital one. My parents have been using a digital scale for years (Weight Watchers) which I always thought was quite good, but I actually like the Omega better because you don't have to tap it for it to come on - you simply step up. Like some other reviewers, I also sometimes weigh myself twice in a few minutes, and each time I get the same result, so I feel the scale is pretty consistent. Overall, I am very happy with this scale and would recommend it to anyone.

  350. This scale is unlike many others I've used - it doesn't require you to &#34;wake it up&#34; by tapping it before you step on. All you do is just calibrate it after each time you move the scale otherwise it doesn't need calibration. Then you just step on when you want to use it, and it quickly measures your weight, blinking the lighted display once it has settled. You can then step off and the reading will remain on the display for a few seconds so you can still see it. This would be useful for trying to weigh luggage, etc, as you don't need to try to read it while the luggage is on the scale.<br /><br />I haven't experienced any problems as yet with this scale, so it gets a 5-star review!

  579. It seems that a bathroom scale, whether digital or analog, should be durable enough to use on a daily basis. I purchased this Epica scale on Amazon in early March, and as of August, it is no longer functional. I had expected to not have to replace the scale for at least a couple of years, and I felt especially assured of the quality since the reviews here seemed so positive. We noticed that the scale started to feel a bit lopsided, and also that the readings were no longer accurate. Upon examination of the device, we found that two of the little rubber feet have metal discs inside that had completely worn through the rubber. These are the pivoting feet that give the scale balance and allow for accurate readings on uneven surfaces like bathroom tile. I completely understand the non-slip rubber for the feet, but the metal that can apparently wear through the rubber in no time seems like a pretty significant design flaw. Also, the features listed here include a 10 second hold, but in the several months that I have had this scale, it has never held the weight at all.

  652. This is by far the best weighing machine I've ever owned and I totally love the slim form factor. So much so that the slim form factor is an inspiration to become slimmer :-)<br />Jokes apart, the machine is accurate and quite effective. I did have an initial scare because the weight on this was almost 6 pounds lower than the weight on my office weighing machine. However, I soon realized the extra weight is usually due to the extra layer of clothing plus the paraphernalia (wallets/cell phones etc) which one typically carries. I tried weighing myself before leaving for office (in complete attire) and the weight was within the margin of error. That apart, I like the large blue LED display, the fact that I don't have to tap on it before I stand on it and that it's extremely light (Makes it much more convenient to stash or store).<br /><br />One of the bigger concerns which people have raised about this weighing machine is the inaccuracy of results or inconsistent operation. I believe this is not a generic problem with the design of this weighing machine but more of a quality control issue. Some people may take this negatively, but one has to understand that it's almost impossible to have 100% quality control. The cost of increasing quality control from say 99.5% to 99.9% may be so prohibitive that it may not be practical for either the seller or the buyer. And that's just not true of a cheap weighing machine! In fact if you do have some time try reading some of the reviews on Canon L series lens (or equivalent ones from Nikon or any other brand). These are professional grade lens and usually cost upwards of a couple of grand, however even those it's not uncommon to have the odd variant which doesn't perform as well as it should. (The real professionals even have extensive setups to test the quality of the lens and may buy/replace 2 or 3 versions before they settle on one). So what can we do as customers, just count our losses and move on? Well that's where Amazon comesto rescue, they have this amazing 30 day 'no-questions-asked' return policy (And if any Amazon reps are reading this, I love you guys for it!!) which even covers shipping. So if you do happen to be unfortunate enough to end up with a faulty version, just send it back to Amazon and order a new one :-)<br />(Oh and as a disclaimer, I use this as a rule of thumb only if around 80 - 90% of reviews are positive; On the other hand if most reviews are negative, its just a bad product!!)<br /><br />So, to summarize, don't judge this product based on a few bad reviews, it's one of the best weighing machines available out there at this price point and if you buy it you wont be disappointed; Well at least I wasn't :-)

Long story short, this scale does not pass the standard simple scale test: place on hard floor, step on, weigh yourself, step off, repeat 3 times after rotating the scale 90 degrees to one side. If a scale is good, your four measurements will not be different by more than half pound. With this scale I am getting random results within 5 pounds of my 190 lb weight. I never have time to return crap, so most likely I will just keep this one and weigh myself with the scale in the same position all the time, hoping the margin of error will be minimal.

  733. I am finally writing a review for this. I purchased this scale about 2 years ago and the scale finally died. I upgraded for a higher quality scale which also reads BMI and other weight-factors.<br /><br />I compared the Omega to the new one and found that this one weighs you 4-5 pounds heavier than you are. It does not calibrate well. Often you'd have to place it on the floor and turn it on, then off, 2-3 times to get a close-to-accurate reading.<br /><br />Furthermore I'm not very heavy, and I babied this scale the 2 years I owned it. I feel like a 2-year lifespan is a little bit lacking in a scale. The one I owned prior to purchasing the Omega lasted 5 years. My recommendation is spending a little more to get one of the nicer scales on the market that read BMI and have better calibrating options.<br /><br />But for the price the scale is inexpensive and it'll give you at least 2 years of faithful weighing service 4-5 pounds off until it dies suddenly in the middle of the night.

One perk I really enjoy is how thin the scale is. I can slide it underneath the cabinet and don't have to worry about it. Another perk is that the numbers on the screen are easy to read, which I really like. The design is also very nice. Overall, this is a great product to add to your home if you are looking for a bathroom scale. Update 2/27/2015 I've noticed that the scale isn't always accurate. Sometimes I will step on, weigh myself, step off, wait a bit, and then step back on again and my weight changes by a few pounds. I haven't done anything during this \\"waiting period\\" besides brush my teeth or comb my hair, etc., something that shouldn't change my weight. Since I've noticed this, I always weigh myself twice to make sure I get an accurate reading. Because of this, I have dropped my rating from a five star to a four star. It is still a decent bathroom scale, but just be a little wary if you only use it once in a short period to weigh yourself.

After a week of use, I no longer have any worries about the product. It's exactly 20mm thin, and sits sturdy on its four rubber legs. I did try using it on the carpet, but it unfortunately isn't made to do so. The best part of this product is the fact you don't have to manually calibrate it, like many others on the market. It's as easy as stepping on, waiting for the LCD screen to blink, and step off. Your weight is displayed for 10 seconds before the unit turns itself off. As you can see from my video, the scale is very accurate. Out of the three times I stepped on the scale, it gave me the exact same reading (down to the .1 of a pound).<br /><br />I have no complaints and would STRONGLY recommend this product to someone looking for an affordable bathroom scale with all of the extra features of a more expensive unit!   934. This scale is extremely thin and very handsome. When you step on you can see it searching for exactly the right weight for you at the moment. But there are a few things you must consider. The scale MUST be on a hard, solid, EVEN floor. The slightest variation in the leveling of the floor will prevent the scale from finding your weight. So you've got to put it in a perfectly hard, level spot, or move it to one when you use it. If you move it every time you use it, you MUST not only put it on a hard, level surface, you must use your forefoot to apply pressure to put some weight on the scale to turn it on, take your foot off, and wait for the scale to turn itself off. Only then can you get on it and get an accurate weight reading for yourself. You cannot use this on a carpet.<br /><br />So if you do all these things, it's great. If you're too lazy, forget it.

  984. So recently I have been tracking my weight because of a &#34;juicing diet&#34; aka reboot. I’ve had a cheap Wal-Mart scale I got almost two years ago but unfortunately the weight wasn’t accurate. The problem was I would get a different weight every time I stepped on the scale (within 5 minutes). So after 3 weeks of juicing I noticed that my weight went down fast but thought &#34;hey it must be the faulty scale&#34;, so I decided to get a new one.<br /><br />I was on groupon and saw one on sale for $25 but decided to check out Amazon for reviews and comparison. That is when I came across the Omega Ultra Slim. The price was roughly $2.50 less but the capacity and style was what got me.<br /><br />I got the scale yesterday and I tried it a couple of times and even thou the LCD screen doesn’t always stay lit, once it did the weight was the same regardless of how many times I got on it. Accuracy was my goal and the Omega is very accurate. Only gripe is that I wish the screen would lock my weight more consistently and not turn off causing me to get on it again.<br /><br />So for those of you interested in the back story, after checking my weight with the Omega I am down 15lbs. Wooohooo!<br /><br />I would recommend this scale for price and accuracy.
  985. This is the best bathroom scale I've owned. It's accurate (agrees with my doctor's scale), repeatable to the tenth of a pound, and has a large back-lit display that I can read in the dark without my glasses. It's stable and low profile, and inexpensive. The platform is more than large enough for size 12 feet. I have the scale on a flat, hard floor, so I cannot speak to how it works on carpet. I can't think of negative thing to say about the scale right now. I've had the scale for about 6 weeks, and the battery is holding up fine. My wife, child, and I use it daily.<br /><br />Update:<br />The scale failed due to my daughter getting on to it weigh while soaking wet. Water made it's way into the electronics and ruined the scale. I ordered a new one to replace it and it is now located in my bed room where it will not see water again. I still recommend the scale, but it should not be used where it might get wet. I've reduced my rating from 5 stars to 4 since it should be water resistant in my opinion.

On good flat surfaces though this works excellent. The number lights up at the top so you don't even need light to see your weight. Make sure to stand on the scale for a good few seconds until it blinks, which means that it is done adjusting and is giving you your weight.

  1172. This scale is very light-weight, has a back-light screen that allows for easy reading of the numbers, and has four little non-skid feet on the bottom so that it will stay in place on a tile or linoleum floor.<br /><br />There are a few issues, though.... The first is that the description is ever-so-mildly inaccurate. It says up to 400 pounds... the scale has a sticker on it that actually says 396. While I'm sure that for most people, that's not going to be much of an issue at all, there will be one or two for whom it causes a problem. My major issue, though, is that the wait fluctuates. When standing on the scale, the numbers bounce back and forth, back and forth... and it doesn't settle on something - it just turns off.<br /><br />I would have expected (and appreciated) that maybe it would lock-in the weight so that it can be viewed from off the scale (after-all, with such a large population of obese individuals in the US, it's likely many will have trouble viewing the numbers from atop the scale). While I don't really have any problems seeing the numbers from on the scale, it's sort of frustrating that the numbers bounce around. There isn't one weight - it's a dozen different possibilities.<br /><br />I suspect I'll probably return the scale... while for most, it will probably work quite well, I need a bit more of a concrete measurement of my weight. I am getting ready for bariatric surgery, and will need to closely monitor my weight after the operation. With the scale not setting in on one weight, that becomes sort of complicated.
  1173. Bought this to replace a dead one. It looks nice and seems to give consistent readings. The display is easy to read and, most importantly, it really is instant on. Step on it and read your weight. That's about as complicated as I want it in the morning, before I had my coffee.
  1174. This little scale is performing great so far. Sometimes it takes a little while to make up its mind, but ultimately settles on just about the same weight as the big, old-fashioned, non-digital scale at the gym. It starts thinking as soon as you step on it, which is great since I have a theory that the \\"light tapping\\" some scales require throws off the calibration with time (let's face it, we occasionally stomp if the first light tap doesn't do the trick). It's as light and slim as it looks in the picture, and very easy to set up. I would have given it 5 stars if I had been using it longer, and if it were a bit smaller - For the slim design, I find it just about 1-2\\" sq. too big. Packaging was not excessive, so not too much trash, delivery was prompt and issue-free.

  1221. I waited a couple of months to evaluate this scale based on daily use and overall accuracy. I prefer not to write reviews that start with...&#34;I just received this item today and it is awesome&#34;. Anyway, I have owned this scale for a couple of months now and believe that I can give it an accurate and fair review. So, if you don't want to read any further, I would say save your money and buy a different scale. For those that care to read further, here is my overall impression...In case you haven't noticed there are multiple scales being sold on Amazon right now by numerous companies. Its almost as if there is some sort a cut throat scale industry fighting tooth and nail for your dollar. Who knew? I read through many of the reviews and I was lead to believe the Omega Ultra Slim Digital Bathroom Scale would meet my needs. I was wrong and sorely misled. I had 4 requirements when shopping for a scale: 1. It has to be a material other than glass. I have small children and a glass scale would inevitably lead to a broken scale and mostly likely tears and blood. Therefore, glass was not an option. 2. It could not be big and bulky. I wanted a low profile scale I didn't have to constantly move around my bathroom. 3. It had to have a highly visible display. At 5:30AM or 10:00PM I don't want to strain my eyes or put on my glasses to read the scale. 4. Finally, the most important feature of all, it must be consistently accurate. This scale met the first three requirements easily. It seems to be constructed of quality plastic. I was able to place it in a location on the floor where it is unobstructed by the bathroom door opening. It has a beautiful large display that is easy to see. Unfortunately, that's where the positives end. This scale failed the last test, accuracy. This scale is not accurate. If I step on the scale, I will get one reading. When it goes blank and I step on it again within seconds, it is almost as if it has an internal memoryand gives the exact same reading. If I step on the scale 3 minutes later, I get a completely different reading. This happens repeatedly. To test the accuracy of the scale, I placed a 75lb dumbbell on the scale three different times. First reading was 72.8lbs, Second reading was 73, Third reading was 73.4. This scale just isn't consistently accurate. Some might think my review is a bit unfair, seeing as how the scale meets three out of my four criteria. Perhaps, but I bought a scale and the purpose of a scale is to accurately measure weight. When a product fails at its primary purpose, then it doesn't deserve a rating above 1 star. So, if you are looking for a scale that will give you a ball park weight, then this might work for you. If you want a scale that gives you an accurate and consistent weight, look elsewhere.
  1222. I give this scale a 5 star rating. It is thin, weighs in .2 pound increments, and is easy to read with large black on blue numbering. And, it is well-priced. If you're looking for a scale, look no further.
  1223. I bought this scale after I moved out of my family home and into a new apartment. My parent's scales (not this one - they've had more than a few over the years) never seemed to work. I would weigh myself a few minutes apart and the weight would change by up to 5 lbs. It would also change depending on orientation, where on the scale you stood, etc. I did not want any of this hassle, so I took way more time than I should have reading reviews for different scales on Amazon, and landed on this one. Have had it for 3-4 years now and I have never had a problem with it. I try to screw it up by moving it around the bathroom, standing on the edges, etc, and it always gives the same result. Unfortunately the weight it says is higher than what I would like it to be, but that seems more like a user problem than an issue with the scale itself. This scale is very accurate, although I wish it would lie to me every once in a while, or at least console me when it reads a higher result than it is used to.

All scales are different, but I was surprised how close this number was to the office's number. I'm glad of that (if not so happy with the number itself, haha).<br /><br />The low profile of the scale means that you do have to look down a decent amount to see the display, so if you're bigger you may have to step a little, but the number stays so it should be fine.   1416. The build quality is excellent. I've owned heavy scales in the past. But this one is unbelievably thin & light, it's so easy to carry from one room to another. But that portability itself is its problem. Because once you move it even slightly, the scale needs to be calibrated. It takes 2 or 3 attempts (stepping on it & off it) before it returns the correct reading. I have also noted that the reading tends to be off by a little (0.1-0.2 Kg) if you don't use the scale for a few days. The display is nice & large with a blue backlight. It certainly scores in the looks department. And the price is also very reasonable. I hope Omega improves the sensor accuracy & calibration.

  1421. I ordered this product to keep track of my weight loss through dieting and exercise, and received it this past Monday.<br /><br />Pros:<br />- The screen is nice and bright, the lock in feature is nice<br />- The scale looks nice and is relatively small, making it an easy fit for any bathroom floor.<br />- The step on to activate feature seems to work fairly well<br /><br />Cons:<br />- Build quality. If you're nearing the high end of the range this scale offers, you may encounter troubles with maintaining the scale. Embarrassingly, the scale made loud cracking noises and felt physically stressed during my first attempts at using it (I am within the higher end of what this scale supports). While I cant say for certain that the build quality is an issue, I would have to imagine that the sounds I heard were not in fact part of the feature set of the scale.<br />- Reliability. If you're nearing the end of the range this scale offers you may encounter issues with unreliable weight measuring. I got mixed readings despite multiple recalibrations of the scale. I am not sure if this is an issue that exists within lower ranges of the scale, as I had someone else test it and they received fairly similar results each time.<br />- Confusing/Misleading instructions. The instructions state in three different places that you must calibrate the scale before you use it (and any time when you move it afterwards), yet each of the places describes a different method in which it has to be done. The manual will state that you need to just replace the batteries and do nothing with it, while another place will mention that you need to stand on it and let it turn off without getting off, and yet another place will mention tapping the bottom unit button/tapping the scale to get it to calibrate back to 0. With some trial and error, you'll figure it out, but if bad English makes you weary of products then you might look elsewhere.<br /><br />Conclusion: If you're in the higher range that thisscale supports, you might be better off buying a slightly more expensive model with higher build quality and more reliable measuring for larger weights. I myself have returned my product and am now looking for a better scale to utilize. However, I am still rating this an average as it managed to do all the features it promised, and appears to be a good value deal for those in the lower range who needn't worry about the build quality or other issues above.
  1422. This is the worst scale I've ever owned. It's totally inaccurate and undependable. The results vary by as much as 5 to 8 pounds. You can weigh yourself 3 consecutive times within minutes and it will give 3 different readings. Sorry I purchased it.
